summaries.body: Bruce Springsteen's autobiography, “Born to Run,” will be published Sept. 27, and the rock star said it would cover the “poetry, danger and darkness” of his New Jersey childhood.

display_asset.caption: A woman with a picture of Tamir Rice during a protest over the fatal 2014 shooting of the 12-year-old by a Cleveland police officer.

summaries.body: The city of Cleveland has rescinded its pursuit of $500 in medical costs from the family of Tamir Rice, 12, who was killed by the police while holding a pellet gun in 2014.

display_asset.caption: James Woods in 2012. He is seeking $10 million worth of damages from an anonymous Twitter user.

summaries.body: A California judge has put the actor James Woods closer to unmasking an anonymous Twitter user he claims defamed him.
Morgan Stanley will pay $3.2 billion in a settlement with state and federal authorities over its creation of mortgage-backed bonds before the financial crisis.

display_asset.caption: Lincoln Center Plaza.
display_asset.credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

summaries.body: The inaugural class of the Lincoln Center Hall of Fame will comprise Louis Armstrong, Plácido Domingo, Yo-Yo Ma, Audra McDonald, Leontyne Price and Harold Prince.

display_asset.caption: An HSBC branch in central London. The lender announced on Thursday that it would reinstate pay increases after receiving feedback from employees.

summaries.body: HSBC, which unveiled plans last month to freeze hiring and pay, now says it will allow pay increases this year but will keep the hiring ban in place.

display_asset.caption: People waited for news outside Topo Chico Prison in Monterrey, Mexico, on Thursday.

summaries.body: Dozens of people were killed in a prison riot in northeastern Mexico, days before a planned visit by Pope Francis to another prison in the country.

display_asset.caption: Reinhold Hanning, center, a former guard at Auschwitz, in court in Detmold, Germany, on Thursday.

summaries.body: The trial of Reinhold Hanning, 94, a former guard at Auschwitz charged with being an accessory to the murder of at least 170,000 people, opened in Germany on Thursday.
A 25-year-old Jewish man dressed in Hasidic clothing was stabbed in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, in what the police are investigating as a possible hate crime.
A wild elephant went on a seven-hour rampage through an Indian town before it was tranquilized.

display_asset.caption: From left, Alba Rohrwacher, Nick James, Lars Eidinger, Meryl Streep, Clive Owen, Brigitte Lacombe and Malgorzata Szumowska, members of the competition jury for the Berlin International Film Festival.

summaries.body: This year's Berlin International Film Festival, which opens Thursday, includes a number of films about immigration and refugees.
The California Coastal Commission voted to fire its executive director, Charles Lester, in a defeat for environmentalists who said the move would aid developers.

display_asset.caption: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the drug trafficker known as El Chapo, being escorted to a helicopter at Mexico City’s airport last month.

summaries.body: Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the drug kingpin known as "El Chapo," would face trial in Brooklyn if Mexico agrees to extradite him, a law enforcement official said.
When Beyoncé proudly proclaimed that she kept hot sauce in her bag, it spoke to a mix of black history and Southern pride, a writer says.

display_asset.caption: From left, Kendall Jenner, Kanye West, Kris Jenner, Kylie Jenner, Ian Connor and ASAP Rocky at the unveiling of the new line Kendall & Kylie.
display_asset.credit: Billy Farrell and David X Prutting/BFA

summaries.body: The sisters Kendall and Kylie Jenner unveiled a new fashion line in the run-up to New York Fashion Week. The goal, Kendall said, was to create “simple everyday stuff.”
Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's chief, personally denounced comments from a Facebook board member who suggested that colonialism aided India's economy.

display_asset.caption: Los Angeles County sheriff’s officers at the site where an infant was fatally shot in Compton, Calif.
display_asset.credit: Robert Gauthier/Los Angeles Times, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A 1-year-old girl resting in her crib and surrounded by family in Compton, Calif., was mortally wounded when a bullet came through the garage door, the police said.

display_asset.caption: Todd Ewen had 36 goals and 1,911 penalty minutes in his 11-season N.H.L. career, which ended in 1997.

summaries.body: Autopsy results showed that the N.H.L.'s Todd Ewen, who displayed symptoms of C.T.E. before he killed himself, did not have the brain disease.

display_asset.caption: Bradley Hall at Mount St. Mary's University in Emmitsburg, Md.
display_asset.credit: Bill Green/The Frederick News-Post, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A faculty adviser to the student paper at a Maryland college was fired after it quoted the university president likening struggling students to bunnies that should be drowned.

display_asset.caption: Waris Ahluwalia inside an aircraft with his arms around the shoulders of what appeared to be two Aeroméxico pilots.

summaries.body: A Sikh actor who was not allowed to board an airplane because he refused to remove his turban flew home on Wednesday, ending a two-day standoff with Aeroméxico.
Johns Hopkins said it would become the first hospital in the nation to perform kidney and liver transplants between H.I.V.-positive donors and H.I.V.-positive patients.

display_asset.caption: The emblem of the Communist Party’s Youth League at Minzu University of China in Beijing.
display_asset.credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times

summaries.body: China says its students, including those overseas, must be made ​even more patriotic and devoted to the Communist Party.
Laurent Fabius, the foreign minister of France, ​questioned the commitment​ of the United States to resolving the crisis in Syria, after he announced his resignation.
Scientists have long thought that Lyme disease was caused by just one species of bacteria. But new research suggests that a second species may also cause the illness.
Zdravko Tolimir, a Bosnian Serb former general serving a life sentence on two counts of genocide, has died at 67.
When lobster dishes at 28 restaurants across the U.S. were tested recently, about a third of the samples were found to contain cheap substitutes for lobster.
Dig out those Elsa costumes. Disney's "Frozen" is coming to Broadway in 2018. The musical will feature a team that includes the writers of the blockbuster movie.

display_asset.caption: David Arrigo, an artist, with three paintings of Martin Brodeur, whose Devils jersey was retired.

summaries.body: The Devils honored their longtime goalie Martin Brodeur with a ceremony that drew Lou Lamoriello, the executive who devised the system that let Brodeur flourish.

display_asset.caption: Sylvia Brookoff handed out pickle samples outside the Carnegie Deli on Tuesday. The restaurant had been closed for 10 months, after it was caught stealing gas.
display_asset.credit: Stephanie Diani for The New York Times

summaries.body: New York's iconic Carnegie Deli has reopened after it was ordered closed in April because of the discovery of an illegal gas line hookup.

display_asset.caption: Indian officials gathered at a site on a college campus where a man died and three others were injured.

summaries.body: A bus driver in India was not killed by a meteorite, NASA scientists in the United States said. They believe a “land-based” explosion was the likely cause.
